page.title: 20Landscape Crosthwaite'area'
page.content: The underlying rock in this area is {Carboniferous Limestone,}in contrast to the slates and volcanic rocks found further north.The stone can be seen in the buildings and in the dry-stone walls There are the remains of lime kilns close by, where the limestone from{Whitbarrow Scar }was burnt to make lime for use on the clay-loam soils. The dry-stone walls form the predominant field barrier and are generally kept in good repair by the farmers themselves.The climate is too cold and wet for crop production but is most suitable for grass.The average rainfall is about {70 inches.}The mean summer temperature {18 C.}This study was undertaken by the 23 Junior children aged between 7-12, the Staff and parent 'volunteers' of Crosthwaite C.E. Primary School.June/July 1985.
